title: LA R users group: LA R Users: March Meeting
description:
LA R Users Group will have our March meeting online at https://usc.zoom.us/j/246443859. This our first virtual meetup!

**Talk1** (25min talk, 5min Q&A)
Title: "vctrs: Creating custom vector classes with the vctrs package"
Presented by: Jesse Sadler, Lecturer at Loyola Marymount University

The base R types of vectors enable the representation of an amazingly wide array of data types. There is so much you can do with R. However, there may be times when your data does not fit into one of the base types and/or you want to add metadata to vectors. vctrs is a developer-focused package that provides a clear path for creating your own S3-vector class, while ensuring that the classes you build integrate into user expectations for how vectors work in R. This presentation will discuss the why and how of using vctrs through the example of debkeepr, a package for integrating historical non-decimal currencies such as pounds, shillings, and pence into R. The presentation will provide a step-by-step process for developing various types of vectors and thinking through the design process of how vectors of different classes should work together.

** About Talk1 Speaker **
I am a historian of early modern Europe and currently a lecturer at Loyola Marymount University in Los Angeles. My research investigates the significance of sibling relationships and inheritance in the development of early modern capitalism. I have been using R for approximately two and a half years to analyze and visualize historical data. I am the author of two R packages that should be on CRAN shortly. The opencage package geocodes locations and is written in concert with Maëlle Salmon and Daniel Possenriede, among others. I am also writing a package called debkeepr that integrates non-decimal currencies into R through the basis provided by the vctrs package.

**Talk2** (25min talk, 5min Q&A)
Title: “Starter Guide to R Plumber + Slack”
Presented by: Emad Hasan, Founder & COO at Retina

In this talk, I will cover how you can use R Plumber to interact with Slack and surface analysis and data directly in Slack on demand. More info here https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/starter-guide-r-plumber-slack-detailed-walkthrough-emad-hasan/

** About Talk2 Speaker **
Emad Hasan is currently in charge of Operations & Analytics and is also the Co-Founder of Retina.AI (February 2017-Present) in Los Angeles, CA. Retina.AI focuses on helping executives and managers leverage data science in an easily consumable way. Prior to that, he was the Founder and CEO of Xpertly [masked]), that uses R based analytics to automate introductions between team members of large organizations. Most importantly Mr. Hasan worked as the Head of Business Marketing Operations & Analytics for Facebook [masked]) where he led all analytics and marketing measurement activitiesfor Facebook's business marketing team using data science and machine learning approaches. Prior to Facebook, he worked at PayPal, Booz Allen Hamilton, and Boeing to name a few. Mr. Hasan holds a Bachelor's Degree from Penn State, a Master's Degree in Electrical Engineering from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, and an MBA from UCLA.

title: Colchester R Meetup: Colchester R Users Group - Online Python takeover!
description:
**A meeting link was messaged to everyone that RSVPed. Please message us if you did not receive a link**

Our online March meeting will feature our first Python talk!

We are pleased to announce:

"Basic machine learning with Tensorflow"

Presented by Micha Elsner from the Ohio State University:

"I will demonstrate some simple machine learning applications (classification and sequence modeling for a small natural language dataset) using the Tensorflow library. I'll demonstrate both low-level and high-level APIs, which can be mixed and matched to customize a model for your specific problem. (Although Tensorflow is available for R, my demonstration will be in Python. However, I hope it will be possible to follow along without too much Python expertise.)"

We will webcast this event and include a link close to the meeting time.

Please RSVP as normal. A record of attendees allows us to apply for funding that is necessary for us to continue to operate and is greatly appreciated!

title: Orange County R Users Group (OCRUG): Book club - Session 3 - Feature Engineering and Selection
description:
After the success of our first book club, we are looking to start a new one. Again this will be headed up by Xi Chen. The idea is to motivate us to read books and discussing them together. This will help all of us to develop our skills.

The format will be that the leader will prepare a short summary of the material and present it to the group. We will then discuss the material and do some exercises.

The expectations are that you will attend regularly once you sign up for a book. If you cannot, please wait until the next round starts with a new book. It is also expected that participants will take turns being the leader.

We will meet each week, Wednesday evening between 6:30 and 8:00 PM. The location is the community center at UCI.

Book: Feature Engineering and Selection
http://www.feat.engineering/
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1138079227/

In this event, we will cover chapter 3.

What to bring
* Laptop with R installed
* Book

title: CaRdiff - the Cardiff R User Group: Tidy Thursday: Remote Workshop
group: CaRdiff - the Cardiff R User Group
description:
We have done some interesting R coding in the January and February Meetups. Come join us for our March Tidy Thursday.

Tidy Tuesdays are weekly R projects on 'tidying' data, associated (but not exclusive!) to the 'tidyverse': ggplot2, dplyr, tidyr and friends.

You can find out more about Tidy Tuesdays here: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday

We will meet (on Thursday!), find the most recent data set and 'tidy' it up together.

This session will be very beginner friendly, very hands on, and potentially pair programming driven.

Learning outcomes: Data Preparation, Data Munging, Tidy Data, Tidyverse

It would be helpful for attendees to have the following already installed, but if you run into trouble we can help on the day.

* R: https://www.r-project.org/
* R Studio desktop: https://rstudio.com/products/rstudio/
* Tidyverse: https://www.tidyverse.org/

These are all free tools, and install will take roughly 20-40 min depending on hardware and internet speeds.

title: Spotkania Entuzjastów R-Warsaw RUG Meetup & R-Ladies Warsaw: Why R? Webinar 001 - Achim Zeileis - April 2nd / 8:00 pm GMT+2
group: Spotkania Entuzjastów R-Warsaw RUG Meetup & R-Ladies Warsaw
description:
First Why R? Webinar!

Starting April 2nd, 8:00 pm (GMT+2 / CEST / Warsaw time).
We'll have one 45-60 minutes long talk on YouTube channel.
Visit http://whyr.pl/webinars/ to see the URL for upcoming Live Streams.

You will be able to ask questions on YouTube as comments to the video. You can also visit our Slack http://whyr.pl/slack/ to stay up to date!

# Speaker
Achim Zeileis (Universität Innsbruck)

# Bio
Achim Zeileis is Professor of Statistics at the Faculty of Economics and Statistics at Universität Innsbruck. Being an R user since version[masked], Achim is co-author of a variety of CRAN packages such as zoo, colorspace, party(kit), sandwich, or exams. In the R community he is active as an ordinary member of the R Foundation, co-creator of the useR! conference series, and co-editor-in-chief of the open-access Journal of Statistical Software.

Website: https://eeecon.uibk.ac.at/~zeileis/

# Topic
R/exams: A One-for-All Exams Generator
- Online Tests, Live Quizzes, and Written Exams with R

# Abstract
Many teachers are currently facing the challenge of converting their
courses to distance learning formats that may require many variations of
similar exercises for different learning and assessment formats,
especially in large-lecture courses. In particular, there is an increased
need for online tests and self tests conducted in learning management
systems (such as Moodle, Canvas, Blackboard, etc.), possibly also live
quizzes with voting via smartphones or tablets, and maybe even classical written exams at the end of the semester.

The open-source package "exams" for R (http://www.R-exams.org/) provides a one-for-all approach to automatic exams generation, tying together various open-source packages (in R and beyond). It is based on individual exercises for multiple-choice or single-choice questions, numeric or text answers, or combinations of these. The format can be either in R/Markdown or R/LaTeX containing questions/solutions with some random numbers, text snippets, plots/diagrams, R output, or individualized datasets. The exercises can be combined to exams and easily rendered into a number of output formats including PDFs for classical written exams (with automatic evaluation), import formats for various learning management systems, live voting (via ARSnova), and the possibility to create custom output (in PDF, HTML, Docx, ...).

title: Spotkania Entuzjastów R-Warsaw RUG Meetup & R-Ladies Warsaw: Why R? Webinar 002 - Olgun Aydin - April 9th / 8:00 pm GMT+2
group: Spotkania Entuzjastów R-Warsaw RUG Meetup & R-Ladies Warsaw
description:
Speaker: Olgun Aydin
Title: Introduction to ShinyMobile
Bio + Abstract: below!
Stream: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TJsu0S9_WY4

- channel: http://youtube.com/c/WhyRFoundation
- date: every Thursday 8:00 pm GMT+2 (starting April 2nd!)
- format: one 45 minutes long stream + 10 minutes for Q&A
- comments: ask questions on YouTube live chat
- join Why R? Slack http://whyr.pl/slack/

# Title: Introduction to shinyMobile

Years have passed after Shiny appeared on CRAN at the end of 2012. Since then, the collaborative work of authors, RStudio and R community brought an uncounted amount of improvements and custom extensions. The latter was noticed to provide functionalities for the most customized and fascinating use cases.

Nowadays, in 2020 we are in a comfortable position where the creation of well-designed, client-read Shiny applications takes just a few lines! It is also easier for developers to create extensions for use cases we’ve been starving for! One of such in shinyMobile that allows to create Shiny applications designed for mobile usage!

During the webinar I will describe main elements of Shiny, the concept of miniUI and the elements needed to use shinyMobile. After the introduction to details of the implementation, the plan is to show an example shinyMobile application, designed for the image classification, developed by me.

# Bio:
Olgun Aydin finished his PhD by publishing a thesis about Deep Neural Networks. He works as a Senior Data Scientist in PwC Poland, gives lectures in Gdansk University of Technology in Poland and is a member of WhyR? Foundation. Olgun is a big fan of R and an author of the book called “R Web Scraping Quick Start Guide” , two video courses that are called “Deep Dive into Statistical Modelling with R” and “Applied Machine Learning and Deep Learning with R”. An author of academic papers about the application of statistics, machine learning, and deep learning. He is passionate about statistics, new methods and always enthusiastic to share his experience with all interested in learning data science!

title: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language): Virtual TidyTuesday Meetup! (all are welcome!)
group: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language)
description:
Please join us at the Zoom bridge: https://zoom.us/j/317993370
AND on the R for Data Science Slack Channel #chat_tidytuesday

** If you are not a part of the slack group, you can join by going to r4ds.io/join

Boston useR *virtual* TidyTuesday Meetup
(open to everyone - regardless of location. we also welcome all newcomers, enthusiasts, and experts to participate)

Virtual useR Meetup organized by:
* Asmae Toumi (happy birthday!)
* Kevin Kent
* Rachael Dempsey

#TidyTuesday is a weekly data project aimed at the R ecosystem (see info below). An emphasis is placed on understanding how to summarize and arrange data to make meaningful charts with ggplot2, tidyr, dplyr, and other tools in the tidyverse ecosystem.

This meetup will be hands-on: after a brief introduction of #TidyTuesday and the weekly dataset and two short lightning presentations, everyone will have a chance to explore the data in small groups (via breakout rooms on Zoom) and then share their work with their group. Whether you want to practice exploratory visualization, apply a new analytical technique, try out a new plot theme or just learn tidyverse things from others, #TidyTuesday is for you.

Agenda:
* 5:30: Introductions to useR Meetup & TidyTuesday (Rachael Dempsey & Tom Mock)
* 5:35: Presentation #1 - Meghan Hall: "Good to Great: Making Custom Themes in ggplot2"
* 5:50: Presentation #2 - Kevin Kent: "The science of (data science) teaching and learning"
* 6:00: Introduction to R for Data Science Slack Channel - Jon Harmon
* 6:05: Breakout into groups to work on TidyTuesday dataset - groups will be open for two-hours but you can come and go as you want!

A few additional volunteers will join to jump in and out of groups and help with questions as they arise.

Thank you to:
* Carl Howe
* Jon Harmon
* Josiah Parry
* Meghan Hall
* Priyanka Gagneja
* Tom Mock

To get a sense for #TidyTuesday ahead of time, check out the hashtag on Twitter, explore past datasets or check out David Robinson's screencasts below:

https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCeiiqmVK07qhY-wvg3IZiZQ

title: Montreal R User Group: Model Versioning Done Right: A ModelDB V2 Walkthrough
description:
In a field that is rapidly evolving but lacks infrastructure to operationalize and govern models, ModelDB 2.0 provides the ability to version the full modeling process including the underlying data and training configurations, ensuring that teams can always go back and re-create a model, whether to remedy a production incident or to answer a regulatory query.

Join us on Wednesday, April 1st at 10 AM PDT, for a live walkthrough of the newly released ModelDB V2 and learn how you can streamline your ML model versioning, deployment and monitoring.

Register here: https://hubs.ly/H0nPmP90

If you or a woman in Data Science you know is interested in attending, please click through to RSVP here: https://bit.ly/3aju9Dr

title: Montreal R User Group: AI Model Governance in a High-Compliance Industry
description:
Model governance defines a collection of best practices for data science – versioning, reproducibility, experiment tracking, automated CI/CD, and others. Within a high-compliance setting where the data used for training or inference contains private health information (PHI) or similarly sensitive data, additional requirements are added.

Join us for a live webinar (https://hubs.ly/H0nRfy_0) on April 8th at 11 am PT to learn:

- The additional requirements such as strong identity management, role-based access control, approval workflows, and full audit trail.
- Best practices for establishing a high-productivity data science team within a high-compliance environment.
- How these requirements can be met using John Snow Labs’ Healthcare AI Platform.

Register here: https://hubs.ly/H0nRfy_0

title: IndyUseR Group: (Virtual Meetup) RTrivia - Vijay Lulla, Renv package - Derrick Kearney
description:
This month, our meeting will be held remotely over Zoom video chat at https://zoom.us/j/288343064. There will be no physical location for this meetup.

Join us for two presentation.
1. Vijay Lulla will be leading us in an exploration of the unexpected parts of the R language in a round of R Trivia!
2. Derrick Kearney will share usage scenarios for renv, an R package that helps create portable and reproducible development environments. The package author, Kevin Ushey, explains the basics in his video at https://resources.rstudio.com/rstudio-conf-2020/renv-project-environments-for-r-kevin-ushey . We'll build on top of it with practical usage examples.

All skill levels are welcomed.

title: Portland R User Group: Tidy Tuesday Coding Club
description:
Come join us for a Tidy Tuesday Coding Club. Grow your skills working with and visualizing data together in a low-stress situation. We aim for social coding to learn from each other and expand our skill sets. Our hope is to make this a fun, no-stress, and supportive monthly group where we can all work on data together, discuss challenges, share victories (and grievances), learn about cool new packages and functions, and keep the rust off of our R coding skills!

What is Tidy Tuesday? In the words of the R For Data Science Group: "Every week we post a raw dataset, a chart or article related to that dataset, and ask you to explore the data. While the dataset will be “tamed”, it will not always be tidy! As such you might need to apply various R for Data Science techniques to wrangle the data into a true tidy format. The goal of TidyTuesday is to apply your R skills, get feedback, explore other’s work, and connect with the greater #RStats community! As such we encourage everyone of all skills to participate!" More info here: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday

We’ll select two datasets to work on together in groups, and present our insights to each other at the end.

Rough Schedule:
6:30 - 6:45 Introductions and icebreakers, pick dataset to work on
6:45 - 7:45 Work on dataset in groups (using zoom breakout rooms)
7:45 - 8:00 Wrap up discussion

RSVP to get the zoom meeting information. We'll email it a couple days before the meetup.

title: Sydney Users of  R Forum (SURF): March 2020 - My Favourite ML Package (and Secret Weapon) - Eugene Dubossarsky
description:
We look forward to seeing you at our next R meetup on 11 March with Dr Eugene Dubossarsky.

Arrive from 5:45 pm for a 6 pm talk.

My Favourite Machine Learning and Data Science Package (and Secret Weapon)

Talk synopsis

Watch Eugene crack open a data set with some unusual machine learning tricks and a tool that is his go-to package for starting most machine learning exercises, with a number of unexpected superpowers that other tools just don't have. Eugene will share his favourite R package, along with a few other unusual other ways to interrogate and explore data. He will also introduce a number of his favourite analysis techniques and other tools.

Bio

Dr Eugene Dubossarsky has been a commercial data scientist, financial trader, software developer and professional community leader for over 20 years. He is the principal founder of The Australia New Zealand Data Analytics Network, a community of over 15600 members with regular meetups across the region. His data science training business Presciient has been in operation for over 9 years. He is also the Chief Data Scientist and a Managing Partner of AlphaZetta, a global data analytics training and consulting business spanning 44 countries. He is also a Founding Partner of Advantage Data, a data science technology company, Aurum Data, which leverages AI to value data sets, and risk.earth, innovative cyclone catastrophe risk modelling company.

title: Melbourne Users of R Network (MelbURN): Enterprise Data Science Architecture Conference
description:
Ticket sales are open for the Enterprise Data Science Architecture Conference. Get your tickets at https://edsaconf.io because this is the best place to learn the emerging best practices.

Learn how leading enterprises deploy scalable data science solutions. Connect with leaders in this new field of data science architecture.

The Enterprise Data Science Architecture Conference focuses on how to properly productionise data science solutions at scale. We have confirmed speakers from ANZ Bank, NAB, Coles, SEEK, ENGIE, Latitude Financial Services, Microsoft, AWS, Databricks and Growing Data. The combination of presentations is intended to paint a complete picture of what it takes to productionise a profitable data science solution.

Our field flies fast. Keep your skills current.
As an industry, we are figuring out how to best build end-to-end machine learning solutions. The workflow starts with data sourcing, data preparation, feature engineering, building the machine learning model, testing the ML model, deploying to production, monitoring in production, getting feedback and then repeating the process with improved models and better features. Companies are currently learning how to build it all into one smooth pipeline. The presentations at our conference will show you what works today in leading enterprises. Reserve your place now at https://edsaconf.io because this is a very popular event.

Your toolkit for real projects.
Enterprise scale brings its own challenges and solutions. Automation, resilience, scalability and the appropriateness of the data science techniques used have significant impact on profit and loss. Governance is also important because of privacy laws and because large enterprises often operate in regulated industries. The presentations at our conference will focus on how enterprises are productionising machine learning solutions. We are still learning as an industry. Knowledge of best practices in end-to-end machine learning pipelines will become essential skills - demanded by clients and employers. Keep your skills current. Register at htttps://edsaconf.io because we will showcase the emerging best practices.

Learn from leaders who deploy real data science solutions in their organisations. Our projects have many names: data science, machine learning (ML), artificial intelligence (AI), analytics and other impressive terms. What matters are the results. Increasing profit, saving lives, managing risk, automating manual labour. The presentations at our conference will show you how enterprises are doing it right.

Our industry moves fast. Don't get left behind.
Connect with leaders and build up your toolkit for real machine learning projects. 27th March 2020 at the Melbourne Marriott Hotel. A fully catered conference with coffee, lunch, morning/afternoon tea and evening drinks & canapes. Reserve your place at https://edsaconf.io because this is the place to learn the emerging best practices.

Meet the right people and upskill. As an industry, we are figuring out how to best build end-to-end machine learning solutions. As the field matures, knowledge of best practices in end-to-end machine learning pipelines will become essential skills - demanded by clients and employers. Reserve your place at https://edsaconf.io because you must keep your skills current.

The meetup page is just a placeholder. You need to register at https://edsaconf.io because this is a unique conference.

Best Regards,

Slava Razbash

Enterprise Data Science Architecture Conference

title: BelgradeR: Šta mediji pišu o tech džinovima - analiza sentimenta teksta u R
description:
[VAŽNO] Meetup se ODLAŽE u skladu sa preventivnim merama protiv širenja novog koronavirusa COVID-19. Družićemo se i učiti R zajedno čim se ukaže prilika!

Meetup će biti posvećen uvodu u analizu sentimenta (emotivnog tona) teksta na engleskom jeziku u programskom jeziku R. Principe analize sentimenta ćemo diskutovati kroz minimalnu studiju slučaja predstavljanja tri tehnološka giganta - Apple, Samsung, i Huawei - u onaljn vestima na engleskom jeziku tokom januara i februara 2020.

Oslonićemo se na paket {newsrivr} kako bismo preko Newsriver API pretrage prikupili vesti koje nas interesuju. Pokazaćemo kako jednostavno pre-procesiranje teksta za analizu možemo da izvedemo kombinujući funkcije paketa {tidytext} i {dplyr}. U samoj analizi sentimenta prikupljenih tekstova oslonićemo se na Bing sentiment leksikon koji je dat u paketu {textdata}. Sve vizuelizacije radimo u {ggplot2} dok izveštaj o analizi reprodukujemo u R Markdоwn tokom samog meetupa. Konačno, primenom bejzijanskih A/B testova testitamo hipoteze o tome da li je sentiment bio pozitivniji ili ne u kontekstu vesti dobijenih pretragom za Apple, Samsung, i Huawei.

Meetup je namenjen svim entuzijastima u programskom jeziku R, profesionalcima u Data Science koji žele da steknu uvid u analizu sentimenta teksta, kao i publici koju interesuje mašinska analiza teksta uopšte. Mnogi detalji na koje moramo da obratimo pažnju u razvoju pravih sistema za NLP i analizu sentimenta neće biti obuhvaćeni studijom slučaja koju smo pripremili i njima ćemo posvetiti pažnju na kraju diskusije. Cilj je, pre svega, da se zainteresovani steknu uvid u korake i principe u analizi sentimenta teksta, a R programeri dobiju kod i objašnjenje od koga mogu da počnu i uče dalje ako su zainteresovani.

Predavač će biti dr Goran S. Milovanović, vlasnik konsultantske agencije DataKolektiv i Data Scientist za Wikidata u Wikimedia Deutschland.

Svi materijali su već sada dostupni na GitHub-u: https://github.com/GoranMilovanovic/Belgrade_20200312_SentimentAnalysis_R

----------------------------------------------

The Meetup will provide an introduction to sentiment analysis of English text in the programming language R. The principles of sentiment analysis will be discussed in a mini case study of how three tech giants - Apple, Samsung, and Huawei - were represented by online media in English during the first two months of 2020.

We will relly on the {newsrivr} package to search and collect the relevant news trough the Newsriver API. We will then demonstrate how to perform simple text pre-processing using {tidytext} and {dplyr}. In the sentiment analysis step itself we will rely on the Bing sentiment lexicon present in the {textdata} package. All visualizations will be produced in {ggplot2} while the report on the analysis will be reproduced in R Markdown during the meetup. Finally, we will use Bayesian A/B testing to test a set of simple hypotheses on the sentiment tone in the online media representation of Apple, Samsung, and Huawei.

Lecturer: Goran S. Milovanovic, Phd, DataKolektiv, Owner and Data Scientist for Wikidata, Wikimedia Deutschland.

Materials are already available on GitHub: https://github.com/GoranMilovanovic/Belgrade_20200312_SentimentAnalysis_R

title: EswatiniUseR Group: Exploratory data analysis [wrangling &visualization] and linear modeling using R
description:
After a successful Intro to R session, we are pleased to invite you to another 2-day intensive data analysis workshop using R. The workshop is in collaboration with the Department of Statistics and Demography at UNESWA and R-Forwards.

Our special guest is Dr. Turner and she will be the lead facilitator for the sessions. Dr. Turner is the chair of Forwards and an Honorary Research Fellow of the Statistics Department at the University of Warwick, UK. Additional details about our guest can be found on her website [https://www.heatherturner.net/ ]

Dr Turner will also be visiting a few other Southern African countries (including South Africa, Botswana, and Namibia) during the period. A CrowdFunding campaign is currently running to support her visit. You can also contribute via: https://www.crowdfunder.co.uk/forwards-southern-africa-project-2020# The funds raised will support the running of #rStats workshops/meetups and will be used to further support the African R community.

The sessions will cover exploratory data analysis using R, data wrangling, and data visualization. Participants will also be introduced to linear modeling and reproducible data analytics using R markdown.
Dr. Turner will also give a talk on Forwards, Africa R, and other support available on the broader R community.

We anticipate to host about 20 guests, and we kindly as that you RSVP early to help us plan efficiently. Kindly come with your laptop and install R software (https://cloud.r-project.org/) and R studio (https://rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/) before the date. If you need any help installing the softwares, kindly contact any of the organizers before the date.

We look forward to seeing you there!

title: Campus useR Group Frankfurt: (Virtual) April Meeting: Text Mining Challenge
description:
We are probably all familiar working with numeric, rectangular data in R. However, R also provides a wide range of techniques for analyzing text, known as text mining.

For our April meeting, Khalil offered to give us an insight into different text mining methods in R. In a hands-on exercise following his introduction, we will apply our new knowledge on classic literature texts, publicly available via the Gutenberg project (www.gutenberg.org).

Depending on the number of participants, we may work in groups to see what we came up with. While everyone is invited to participate in friendly competition, this is first and foremost an opportunity to get in touch and learn from each other.

As always, R users of all backgrounds, at all levels of expertise and with all degrees of imposter syndrome are welcome.

Hope to see you in April - for our first virtual useR group meeting!
(video conference tool tba, suggestions welcome)

Edit:

Hi all! If you'd like to follow along and take part in the challenges, these are some of the packages you'd need. Just copy-paste the following into your R console:

install.packages(c("tidyr", "dplyr", "tidytext", "wordcloud", "janeausten", "gutenbergr", "ggraph", "widyr", "igraph", "lubridate", "dslabs", "newsanchor"))

For the newsanchor package, you'd have to get an API key at https://newsapi.org/register/. Follow the instructions at https://github.com/CorrelAid/newsanchor to add your API key to your R environment (alternatively, you can specify it every time you use the package). This will allow us to analyze the news and the hot topics of the day (guess what that is). For the literature analysis, downloading of the text is done very swiftly via the gutenbergr package and I'll leave it up to you to decide which books you'd like to analyze. The janeausten package includes books by the famous British author Jane Austen. Finally, we'll see how to analyze Tweets over time and gain insights into the habits of those who tweet!

title: R-Ladies Brisbane: Spatial data analysis with R [cancelled]
description:
***********
Due to the COVID-19 situation we are cancelling this event.
***********
In this session we have a special international guest!
Dr Reka Solymosi who is a Lecturer in Quantitative Methods at the University of Manchester.

Reka I will talk about how she uses R as a GIS for spatial data analysis. Her main areas of research focus on data about crime, policing, and people's perceptions of place. She will cover descriptive analysis, making thematic and point maps, and some spatial statistics.

Come with your own computer if you want to test this workflow. You will learn about packages such as sf, tmap, leaflet, spatstat and probably some more...!

For more info look at her beautiful R website rekadata.site

We look forward to seeing you there!

Em comemoração ao Dia Internacional da Mulher, reunimos representantes das comunidades AI Girls, PyLadies e R-Ladies Goiânia, com o apoio do IPOG, para incentivar todxs a adentrarem nesse universo também, porque não há nada mais bonito e potente do que mulheres que se juntam numa causa.

A comunidade PyLadies vem com uma palestra com pauta em mulheres na tecnologia. São muitas! Vem saber mais :))

A Thâmara, representante da comunidade AI Girls, chega chegando com a palestra "A Era da Inteligência Artificial". Não perca!

A mesa redonda é extraordinária! Com o tema Machine learning, Deep learning e Redes Neurais Artificiais esperamos ter muita conversa e aprendizado.

Venham bater um papo com a gente, estamos te esperando!

title: R-Ladies Edinburgh: [ONLINE] Scalable Automatic Machine Learning in R with H2O with Erin LeDell
description:
**UPDATE** We are moving this event online, at the same time and day. We will send a Zoom link for the call day prior to the event. Hope you can join us online!

Dr. Erin LeDell is the Chief Machine Learning Scientist at H2O.ai, where she leads the development of an open-source, automatic machine learning (AutoML) platform. Before joining H2O.ai, she worked as a data scientist and software engineer and founded DataScientific, Inc. She’s also the founder of the non-profit Women in Machine Learning & Data Science (WiMLDS.org) organization and co-founder of the R-Ladies Global organization. She received her Ph.D. from UC Berkeley where her research focused on machine learning and statistical computing.

**Scalable Automatic Machine Learning in R with H2O**

The focus of this presentation is scalable and automatic machine learning in R using the H2O machine learning platform. H2O is an open-source, distributed machine learning platform is designed to scale to very large datasets that may not fit into RAM on a single machine. We will provide a brief overview of the field of Automatic Machine Learning, followed by a detailed look inside H2O’s AutoML algorithm. H2O AutoML provides an easy-to-use interface that automates data pre-processing, training and tuning a large selection of candidate models (including multiple stacked ensemble models for superior model performance), and due to the distributed nature of the H2O platform, H2O AutoML can scale to very large datasets. The result of the AutoML run is a “leaderboard” of H2O models which can be easily exported for use in production. R code examples are available on GitHub for participants to follow along on their laptops.

--

Q: Are men welcome to attend this event?
A: Our primary mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. ***As such, we strongly encourage that all men who attend this event have a female or non-binary sponsor. Please contact [masked] if you have questions.***

Additionally, please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies, and by being respectful of the fact that this event is primarily for women/non-binary/female-identifying individuals.

title: BaselR: satRday in Neuchatel

description:
Sentiment Analysis!
___________________________________________________________________________________
The Objective is to create a neural network that can predict if a given movie review is positive or negative. This type of computation is also called Sentiment Analysis.

I will be working with “IMDB data-set”, a set of 50,000 reviews from the Internet Movie Database. They are split into 25,000 reviews for training and 25,000 reviews for testing, each set consisting in 50% negative and 50% positive reviews.

I will use Keras library to build neural network and walk you through building and training model, model tuning with different hyper-parameter (Optimizer, Loss Function, No. of layers, epoch, batch_size ). I will try and improve the accuracy of model by experimenting with different hyper-parameters.

title: R-Ladies Irvine: Sports Statistics, Advancing Your Career in 2020, & R Adoption in the Enterprise
description:
# Schedule
Tuesday, March 17th, 6:30-8:30pm
6:30 - [Online Networking Activity] Zoom Breakout Rooms
6:55 - Announcements
7:00 - [Career Corner] Advancing Your Career in 2020 & R Adoption in the Enterprise
7:20 - 10-Minute Break
7:30 - [R Time] A Sports Statistics Show and Tell
8:30 - Meeting Adjourned

# Meeting Location
Out of an abundance of caution regarding COVID-19 and in order to prioritize the health and safety of everyone who attends our events, the March 17th meeting will be held ONLINE using Zoom.

The meeting link will be sent to registered attendees.
Please use the RSVP button to register!

# Presentations
[Career Corner] Advancing Your Career in 2020 & R Adoption in the Enterprise
Speaker: Louis Columbus

[R Time] A Sports Statistics Show and Tell
Speaker: Jason Wilson, PhD
Abstract:
The contents of this presentation will be drawn from the qopbaseball.com project which began in 2010, two years after I completed my Ph.D in Statistics. It originated with a clever student's IntroStat class final project! The research consists of 1 patent-pending statistical model for calculating the quality of a baseball pitch, 8 million Major League Baseball (MLB) pitches calculated, 12 thousand lines of R code, 15 MLB teams consulted, and 1 active Twitter handle @qopbaseball. In the first part of the presentation (~30min.), I will tell the origin story and development, with special attention given to the R work and lessons learned along the way. The second part of the presentation (~20min.) will be guided according to audience interest. I will take questions on any aspects of the project. I will have code and data on hand for demonstration. Sample data will be provided for audience explorations.

# Live-streaming & Meeting Materials
- All registered attendees will receive a Zoom link to join the meeting. Please see the information above.
- All materials will be sent out and posted on our GitHub (https://github.com/rladies-irvine) after the event.
- The recording of the meeting will be sent out and posted on our YouTube Channel (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCIbS1KNK7jbcbQVNt7lF62A) after the event.

title: R-Ladies Newcastle: POSTPONED: Panel session and meetup pre-SatRday
description:
POSTPONED TO AUTUMN 2020:

R-Ladies Newcastle are pleased to announce we will be hosting a panel session with Julia Silge (https://juliasilge.com/about/), a data scientist and software engineer at R Studio, and Mine Çetinkaya-Rundel (http://www2.stat.duke.edu/~mc301/) a Senior Lecturer in the School of Mathematics at University of Edinburgh and Data Scientist and Professional Educator at RStudio.

The event will be an opportunity for R-Ladies to meet up prior to the SatRdays event taking place the next day, so if you’re in Newcastle the night before please come along. If you’re worried about attending SatRdays alone, then this will be a great chance to meet a few friendly faces who you’ll recognise the next day. Alternatively, if you’d been on the fence of making the journey to Newcastle hopefully this will act as an extra enticement!

We're so excited for SatRdays and hope to see as many R-Ladies members as possible. Tickets can be purchased from: https://newcastle2020.satrdays.org/

About the session:
6:00-7:00pm Panel session (approx.)
7:00-8pm Networking

We need your questions!

The panel session will be a chance to ask Julia and Mine about their career history as R-Ladies and the different focuses their careers have had. Both have had rich and varied careers, so this is a great chance to hear about their experiences. We’ll be taking some questions on the day, but for the best chance of having your questions answered please submit them in the comments below or message one of us organisers.

Example questions:
What was it like moving away from academia? And what advice would you give to others thinking about making the transition
What do you think is the most valuable skill you use in your roles as data scientists?
What is your favourite trick in R? E.g. nifty shortcuts, handy functions
What do you look for when joining a new team?
Do you have any advice on making sure we’re bringing R-Ladies principles in to our jobs?

We anticipate this event will be well attended so book your place asap. As usual, this event is open to those who identify as a marginalised gender.

Acknowledgements

Thank you to the School of Computing for providing the venue and to Sage for providing pizza.

THANKS.

Join us on March 25th to learn more about using flexdashboard in R.

It's an awesome easy way to transform your R markdown documents into great looking interactive dashboards you can share with the world!

Here are some details on this new package (from RStudio):

- Use R Markdown to publish a group of related data visualizations as a dashboard.
- Support for a wide variety of components including htmlwidgets; base, lattice, and grid graphics; tabular data; gauges and value boxes; and text annotations.
- Flexible and easy to specify row and column-based layouts. Components are intelligently re-sized to fill the browser and adapted for display on mobile devices.
- Storyboard layouts for presenting sequences of visualizations and related commentary.
- Optionally use Shiny to drive visualizations dynamically.

We're meeting at 6:30pm at Hera Hub Mission Valley.

We hope to see you all there!

Your R-Ladies SD organizers

title: R-Ladies Ames: Create a personal website with Blogdown
description:

title: R-Ladies El Paso: R-Ladies - ggplot tutorial with Marguerite Mauritz
description:
A note from Marguerite:

Hi Rladies participants,

I will be demonstrating some uses of ggplot, one of R’s graphing packages. I’ll give a short intro and then we’ll do a code-along so that everyone can do their own typing.
We will make a few basic figures and then experiment with customizing to make them pretty.
Some code will be pre-written to make it easier to keep up, and some parts you will have to fill in.

To prepare, please pre-load the Tidyverse package in R, on a WiFi connection.

# Tidyverse has a number of basic packages that all load together using the command:
install.packages(“tidyverse”)
library(tidyverse)

Check that you definitely have:
ggplot2
dplyr
tidyr
readr
On the day of the workshop, we will have the code template and data on USB drives so that you can easily load it to your computer offline. We will use some data that from my research in the Chihuahuan desert looking at rainfall and how water it moves through the soil. It’s for demonstration purposes only and I think has many features that would appear in other data problems.

Tidyverse is a nice set of packages that work together to make coding and data structure smoother.
More information about Tidyverse is here:
https://www.tidyverse.org/packages/

title: R-Ladies Washington D.C.: Books In Bars - How Charts Lie
description:
Spend Friday night discussing How Charts Lie (https://www.amazon.com/How-Charts-Lie-Getting-Information/dp/1324001569).

A leading data visualization expert explores the negative―and positive―influences that charts have on our perception of truth.

We’ve all heard that a picture is worth a thousand words, but what if we don’t understand what we’re looking at? Social media has made charts, infographics, and diagrams ubiquitous―and easier to share than ever. We associate charts with science and reason; the flashy visuals are both appealing and persuasive. Pie charts, maps, bar and line graphs, and scatter plots (to name a few) can better inform us, revealing patterns and trends hidden behind the numbers we encounter in our lives. In short, good charts make us smarter―if we know how to read them.

However, they can also lead us astray. Charts lie in a variety of ways―displaying incomplete or inaccurate data, suggesting misleading patterns, and concealing uncertainty―or are frequently misunderstood, such as the confusing cone of uncertainty maps shown on TV every hurricane season. To make matters worse, many of us are ill-equipped to interpret the visuals that politicians, journalists, advertisers, and even our employers present each day, enabling bad actors to easily manipulate them to promote their own agendas.

In How Charts Lie, data visualization expert Alberto Cairo teaches us to not only spot the lies in deceptive visuals, but also to take advantage of good ones to understand complex stories. Public conversations are increasingly propelled by numbers, and to make sense of them we must be able to decode and use visual information. By examining contemporary examples ranging from election-result infographics to global GDP maps and box-office record charts, How Charts Lie demystifies an essential new literacy, one that will make us better equipped to navigate our data-driven world.

PS Please contact the organizer if you need support finding the book.

title: R-Ladies RTP: [ONLINE] #tidytuesday Work Group
description:
Join fellow R-Ladies in exploring a #tidytuesday data set! Work individually or with the group and end the evening by sharing your work.

We'll explore a new interactive web tool that was recently developed to aid COVID-19 response in Chapel Hill, NC (https://github.com/code-for-chapel-hill/COVID-Support-For-CH). The Code for Chapel Hill group (via Dr. Kate Hanson) has asked us to provide feedback and suggestions for the tool, which was built using the Shiny package in R. We'll also talk to Dr. Hanson about additional volunteer opportunities for data scientists to help local governments in these pressing times.

Agenda:
6:00 - 6:15 pm Meet & Greet
6:15 - 7:30 pm #tidytuesday
7:30 - 8:00 pm Discussion

This is a great opportunity to meet other R-ladies, improve your R skills, and build up your GitHub/Twitter/data science portfolio!

What is #tidytuesday?
#TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project created by the R4DS online learning community that is focused on using tidyverse packages. A new data set and accompanying article featuring an interesting plot is released on Github every Monday. The goal is to generate a copy of the original plot or create your own original approach!

For more information on #tidytuesday, check out this blog post: https://bit.ly/2HqEsdt

Who is this for?
New and experienced R users alike! Let's learn together!

What should I bring?
Please bring your own laptop (fully-charged!) and all learning materials you want to use. If you have time, please look at the data set beforehand and think about some questions you'd like to answer with it.

Where will it take place?
**Please join us online via Zoom.** We'll send out an email to members who have RSVP 'Yes' the day before this event.

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

title: R-Ladies Los Angeles: RLadies LA RMarkdown Virtual Meetup!
description:
Hello RLadies!

Due to the coronavirus situation in LA County, RLadies LA and our other local R users groups are moving our usual meetups online for the next few months. Our first virtual meetup will be Saturday, March 28, at 10am. Amanda Tilot will give a tutorial on using RMarkdown for data analysis and reporting.

"Better data communication & organization with RMarkdown"

What do a static PDF, an interactive HTML document, a personal website, and a slide deck all have in common? You can build them in R with RMarkdown! In this tutorial, we'll work through some common scenarios where RMarkdown can help improve your data communication and organization.

* Shifting from R script files + lots of #comments to RMarkdown notebooks
* Turning your R code into HTML, PDFs, and Word docs with knitr
* Enhancing your RMarkdown files with text formatting and presentation options
* Doing more with code chunks: SQL queries & background jobs

**Schedule**
10:00a - 10:15a Open Zoom, come say hi!
10:15a - 11:00 RMarkdown tutorial
11:00 - 11:15 Extra Q&A, planning future sessions

Have a question about using RMarkdown that you'd like Amanda to cover? Post a comment on the event page!

We'll send out a Zoom link to all attendees closer to the 28th, and include instructions for joining the meetup. All materials from the tutorial will be available on Github afterward.

As always we welcome people regardless of gender, but our group is intended for those who identify with a gender minority (trans women, cis women, trans men, non-binary, other). We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct.

See you there!
Amanda Tilot
@aktilot

PS: We're always looking for presenters! If you're interested, please reach out to Amanda ([masked]) or Katie ([masked]).

title: R-Ladies St. Louis: Qualitative analysis in R ~ Now a VIRTUAL Meetup!
description:
Happening tonight! Mary Painter will lead our first ever online R-Ladies St. Louis Meetup for our very first *qualitative* workshop.

Materials for the Meetup are at https://github.com/rladiesstl/meetupMar2020

The most important things to do before the Meetup so you can follow along:

(1) Install RQDA with dependencies (can take time!)
(2) Download and save the files from the GitHub repository to a folder you can find

How to download and save all the files from GitHub:

(1) Go to the repository https://github.com/rladiesstl/meetupMar2020
(2) Click on Clone or download
(3) Choose Download ZIP
(4) Once download is complete, extract the files to a location you can find

If you already downloaded before 3/17/2020, please note some minor revisions to the first code chunk in the R Markdown file and edit your file or re-download this file.

If you have extra time, open the TMandTidyText.Rmd file from the downloaded materials and change the file paths on lines 15 and 42 to the location where you saved everything for this Meetup.

Reminder: R looks for forward slashes / in file paths! (not \)

Mary Painter is a doctoral candidate in political science at the University of Missouri St. Louis.

title: R-Ladies St. Louis: Making personal websites with blogdown ~ a VIRTUAL workshop
description:
Join us in welcoming Dr. Dorris Scott, who will lead a virtual workshop on how to make your own professional or personal website using the blogdown package in R.

Before the Meetup, make sure you have updated R and R Studio and installed the following packages (if you do not already have them):
- rmarkdown
- blogdown
- tidyverse

Dr. Scott will be posting materials in a GitHub repository on Wednesday or Thursday.

Check out Dr. Scott's website: https://dscott.netlify.com/

title: R-Ladies Seattle: pRedicaments in R: An R-Ladies Remote Rendezvous
description:
Join R-Ladies Seattle for our first remote meeting on debugging and getting help! Inspired by Jenny Bryan's keynote at rstudio::conf (link below), we will take a deeper dive into how to resolve error messages in R.

We have 2 wonderful speakers who will be presenting.

_Christine Stawitz_
* I'll discuss my process for sifting through the (often less-than-helpful) documentation that comes with R packages, including function reference, vignettes, and GitHub issue forums.
* I'm a contractor at ECS Federal in support of NOAA Fisheries' Office of Science and Technology. I work on improving coding, documentation, and sharing practices for the software NOAA and academic fisheries scientists use to manage marine resources.

_Katie Jolly_
* I'll talk about using the {reprex} package for creating reproducible examples. This package makes it easier to write clear, concise, and readable code questions that will get a more helpful response in return.
* I am a data analyst at Ookla. I am interested in spatial data, information design, and civic data projects.

Details:
* We will send out conference call information to attendees who have RSVP'd "Yes" to this event. The call will be taking place over zoom.
* Thank you to Ookla for helping us get set up with zoom!

Link to Jenny Bryan's talk in case you'd like to view it before our meeting (not required!):
https://resources.rstudio.com/rstudio-conf-2020/object-of-type-closure-is-not-subsettable-jenny-bryan

title: R-Ladies Fayetteville: Cari Bogulski on Data Cleaning and Alt-Academic Career Paths
description:
THIS EVENT WILL NOW BE AN ONLINE EVENT FOLLOWING THE CLOSING OF THE BREWER HUB IN LIGHT OF COVID 19.

Here is the link to tomorrow's (3/17) R-ladies WebEx remote meeting at 12:15pm:
https://uark.webex.com/uark/j.php?MTID=mc1aaf5d59905560ee0e0bcb5b3c4f14f

We hope you all can join! When you join the meeting please mute your audio and ask questions via the chat box.

Cari is very happy to present on data cleaning and some of what she does. In particular, she will talk about program evaluation as an interesting alt-ac possibility that she hadn't heard of when she was in graduate school.

title: Taiwan R User Group / MLDM Monday: MLDM Monday｜自然語言理解於價值函數的強化學習應用
group: Taiwan R User Group / MLDM Monday
description:
講題：自然語言理解於價值函數的強化學習應用

講者：JerryWu
現任 Google 機器學習開發專家 (GDE)、APMIC OpenTalk 創辦人兼執行長，專注於自然語言理解 (NLU) 技術與應用。曾任國立台灣科技大學講師、外商數據科學顧問、汽車業資深數據科學顧問、DSP 智庫驅動共同創辦人兼技術長，歷經許多產、官、學、研機器智能專案。

大綱：
談談 NLU 與 RL 整合的實作
1. 為何要做自然語言理解
2. 什麼是價值函數與BERT
3. 概念展示

注意事項：
為避免群聚感染風險、以及配合衛生防疫機關後續健康追蹤，本次活動（MLDM Monday 自然語言理解於價值函數的強化學習應用）需麻煩參加者據實填寫此健康聲明書（ https://forms.gle/G1vQLxrtR8FRyR4KA ） ，其個人填寫資料「僅使用於」衛生防疫機關後續健康追蹤用途，並於「 90 日」內全部刪除．
To avoid the risk of cluster infection and follow-up health tracking, the participants of this event need to fill this health statement. The personal information is "only used for" follow-up health tracking and it will be deleted in 90 days.

若參加活動後 14 天內如出現可疑症狀，麻煩請與活動主辦單位 Taiwan R User Group 聯絡，並撥打防疫專線 1922 依指示戴口罩儘速就醫．
If you have suspicious symptoms after participating in this event, please dial the CDC epidemic line 1922 and contact with Taiwan R User Group event organizers, then seek medical treatment as soon as possible.

title: R-Ladies Gainesville: Tidy Tuesday: Practicing Data Science in R
description:
Practice your data wrangling and visualization R skills with other members of R-Ladies! Tidy Tuesdays are designed by the R for Data Science Online Learning Community to help R users learn in a fun and real-world context.

Read more about Tidy Tuesdays here: https://www.tidytuesday.com/

We will be converting our regular Tidy Tuesdays to an online format. Join us on Zoom at: https://ufl.zoom.us/j/690685801

If you've never used Zoom before, you will be prompted to download something. You will be muted automatically upon entering the meeting - so unmute if you'd like to communicate with us/each other. Depending on how many people join, we might have to turn off webcams at some point. But we'd love to see your faces, so rather not :) Don't worry about pets and family members in frame, we'd love to see them too.

These events will supplement, not replace, our monthly meetings.

title: R-Ladies Gainesville: March meeting: Shiny apps
description:
Always wondered how to make interactive apps in R?

Mel Moreno will be presenting on how to create Shiny apps: she will take you through the basics, show how to create linear and multi-functional models, and eventually maps.
These are some of the Shiny apps Mel has made:
https://oysterprojectck.shinyapps.io/landing/ (landings for oyster project)
https://oysterprojectck.shinyapps.io/river_quantile/ (river discharge for oyster project)

This is the first time we're trying to do our R-Ladies meeting online: we will use Zoom. If you've never used Zoom before, you will be prompted to download something. You will be muted automatically upon entering the meeting - so unmute if you'd like to communicate with us/each other. Depending on how many people join, we might have to turn off webcams at some point. But we'd love to see your faces, so rather not :) Don't worry about pets and family members in frame, we'd love to see them too. Just make sure everyone is wearing pants (the family members, not the pets).
Also - we've heard some rumors of Zoom meetings being spammed with people screen sharing with unwanted information, so we will try to avoid that.

title: R-Ladies Dallas: March R-Ladies Meetup - Online
description:
Join us for our March R-Ladies Community Meetup, where we’ll get to know one another and learn new ways to grow our skills as R users and data scientists/analysts.

We will follow community guidance against in-person gatherings and have this event online via Zoom.

If you'd like to attend, please fill out this form. You will receive an invitation to the Google Hangouts session.

Here's a tentative agenda:
* We will spend some time socializing and reacquainting ourselves with one another.

* We will discuss some of the issues you might be facing in this new, quickly changing landscape.

* If there is interest, we can discuss the R-Ladies coding challenge

Feel free to reach out to Sydeaka at at [masked] if you have any questions!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

About R-Ladies Dallas

R-Ladies Dallas welcomes members of all R proficiency levels, whether you're a new or aspiring R user, or an experienced R programmer interested in mentoring, networking & expert upskilling. Our non-profit, civil society community is designed to develop our members' R skills & knowledge through social, collaborative learning & sharing. Supporting minority identity access to STEM skills & careers, the Free Software Movement, and contributing to the global R community!

A local chapter of R-Ladies Global, R-Ladies Dallas exists to promote gender diversity in the R community worldwide. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R. As a founding principle, there is no cost or charge to participate in any of our R-Ladies communities around the world.

Q: Are men welcome to attend R-Ladies events?
A: Yes, men are welcome at this event. Our mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. Please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies, and by being respectful of the fact that this event is primarily for women/non-binary/female-identifying individuals.

We expect all attendees to abide & be governed by our community code of conduct. Please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct.

title: R-Ladies Cuernavaca: Tercer  Meetup R-Ladies Cuernavaca: Generación de gráficas con ggplot2
description:
En nuestro Tercer Meetup de R-Ladies Cuernavaca tendremos una invitada especial, la Dra. Ernestina Godoy Lozano del Instituto Nacional de Salud Pública nos hablará sobre cómo generar gráficas con el paquete ggplot2.

Conocimientos necesarios:
- Manejo de Data frames
- Lectura y escritura de archivos en R.

Fecha: Viernes 20 de Marzo de 2020.
Lugar: Aula 3 de la Licenciatura en Ciencias Genómicas dentro del Centro de Ciencias Genómicas de la UNAM

PROGRAMA
16:15 Bienvenida.
16:30 Introducción a ggplot2
17:30 Coffee Break.
18:00 Generación de gráficas.

Importante: TRAE TU TAZA para el coffee break!! Estamos comprometidas con el Programa Basura Cero de la UNAM, por lo que NO tendremos vasos desechables.

REQUISITOS:
- Leer y atender el código de conducta disponible (https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct/)
- Traer tu computadora personal.
- Instalar R y RStudio última versión.
- Instalar el paquete ggplot2 con install.packages("ggplot2").

Si no te es posible asistir al evento, por favor cancela tu inscripción al menos 24 horas antes del evento para darle oportunidad a las personas en lista de espera.

En este evento tendremos una sala de actividades para niños, cuéntanos durante tu registro cuántos pequeñines te acompañarán al evento y sus edades para diseñar las actividades más divertidas para ellos.

Agradecemos a nuestros patrocinadores: R Consortium (https://www.r-consortium.org), el Centro de Ciencias Genómicas y el Instituto de Biotecnología de la UNAM.

title: R User Group Eindhoven: Introduction to Statistics with R - Session 3 of 3 - Re-scheduled
description:
This event is re-schedule as some of the members who attended earlier session could not travel due to concern about corona virus.

We will develop concepts of distributions and confidence interval.

For distributions, we will especially focus on normal distributions which are also known as Guassian distributions.

We will then develop notion of confidence interval (e.g. based on observed data, how can we say that there is 95% chance that a measurement will lie between a certain interval of values)

This session is planned longer (3 hours) to have enough time to develop those concepts.

We will also plan some exercises to allow the participants to develop their understanding further. (So please bring laptops).

title: Orange County R Users Group (OCRUG): Book club - Session 7 - Feature Engineering and Selection
description:
After the success of our first book club, we are looking to start a new one. Again this will be headed up by Xi Chen. The idea is to motivate us to read books and discussing them together. This will help all of us to develop our skills.

The format will be that the leader will prepare a short summary of the material and present it to the group. We will then discuss the material and do some exercises.

The expectations are that you will attend regularly once you sign up for a book. If you cannot, please wait until the next round starts with a new book. It is also expected that participants will take turns being the leader.

We will meet each week, Wednesday evening between 6:00 and 7:30 PM. The location is Zoom

Book: Feature Engineering and Selection
http://www.feat.engineering/
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1138079227/

In this event, we will cover chapter 7.

What to bring
* Laptop with R installed
* Book

title: Central Iowa R User Group: R and Python study group
description:
We don't know when we'll be able to meet in person. In the meantime we have set up a Slack workspace where we can stay in touch, ask questions, and share information relevant to the group on an ongoing basis. (Not just on Saturday mornings.)

You can join the Central Iowa R User Group workspace using the following link:

https://join.slack.com/t/centraliowarusergroup/shared_invite/zt-cpylz1v6-RqmvYIolB6lgV1wTJWVXzg­

Are you tired of learning and playing with Python and R alone? Would you like to get together with a few friends and learn together? I have been starting to learn R and Python for data science and following the typical route of videos and practice projects. I really want to ramp up my learning and exposure to different ways. Here is my proposal:

- Gather a small group of 2-5 and learn together.
- Meet at a coffee shop, library, or some other space that has Wi-Fi.
- Pick a project, data set or problem, then work to solve it with different tools.
- Keep it fluid and informal.
- Meet on a regular basis, say weekly to start, and adjust as needed.
- Aim to keep the meetings 2-4 hours long, but this can be adjusted to the project or group. People can come and go as needed.
- It does not have to be the same people each time, so you only have to commit to going once to check it out.

Are you interested? Show up at the meeting spot, have some coffee, meet new friends and bring a project or question.

title: Central Iowa R User Group: R and Python study group
description:
Are you tired of learning and playing with Python and R alone? Would you like to get together with a few friends and learn together? I have been starting to learn R and Python for data science and following the typical route of videos and practice projects. I really want to ramp up my learning and exposure to different ways. Here is my proposal:

- Gather a small group of 2-5 and learn together.
- Meet at a coffee shop, library, or some other space that has Wi-Fi.
- Pick a project, data set or problem, then work to solve it with different tools.
- Keep it fluid and informal.
- Meet on a regular basis, say weekly to start, and adjust as needed.
- Aim to keep the meetings 2-4 hours long, but this can be adjusted to the project or group. People can come and go as needed.
- It does not have to be the same people each time, so you only have to commit to going once to check it out.

Are you interested? Show up at the meeting spot, have some coffee, meet new friends and bring a project or question.

title: STWUR - Wroclaw R Users Group Meetup: WAMPIR #4 Online - Machine Learning i Networking
group: STWUR - Wroclaw R Users Group Meetup
description:
Hej!

Społeczność Wrocławskiego Aliansu Miłośników Pythona i R tym razem spotyka się online.

Gościem spotkania będzie dr Adam Gonczarek.

Temat:
Jak przewidzieć rozwój pandemii SARS-CoV-2 w Polsce przy pomocy modeli matematycznych i uczenia maszynowego?

Pandemia koronawirua jest bez wątpienia tematem, którym żyje obecnie cały świat. W ramach prezentacji pokażę, na czym polega modelowanie epidemii i jakie podejścia mogą być tutaj zastosowane. Zaprezentuję podstawowe modele epidemiologiczne oparte o równania różniczkowe oraz ich rozszerzenia. Ponadto przedstawię jak dopasować modele do bieżących danych, korzystając z technik uczenia bayesowskiego. Na koniec pokaże jak z wykorzystaniem tych modeli można prognozować różne scenariusze przebiegu pandemii w zależności od podjętych działań, mających na celu hamowanie jej rozwoju.

Adam Gonczarek jest współzałożycielem i szefem technologii w Alphamoon, polskiej firmie świadczącej usługi z zakresu sztucznej inteligencji i uczenia maszynowego. Posiada doktorat z informatyki z Politechniki Wrocławskiej, gdzie pracował również jako adiunkt do 2019. Swoje doświadczenie zdobył pracując jako wykonawca, konsultant i lider zespołów AI w projektach B+R i projektach komercyjnych, zarówno dla dużych firm, jak i startupów.

Sponsorem spotkań i fundacji WhyR? jest firma Kruk S.A.

title: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language): Virtual April useR: Coronavirus Propagation Modeling
group: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language)
description:
April useR Meetup
Coronavirus Propagation Modeling led by Anton Antonov

Zoom bridge to be added day before event**

In this (tutorial) presentation, Anton will:

* Discuss the modeling and evolution of different scenarios of the coronavirus propagation and related decease
* Overview classic compartmental models in epidemiology
* Discuss the theory behind the System dynamics approach using simple examples
* Discus philosophical, scientific, and mathematical justifications
* Describe System dynamics' approaches of modeling the propagation of SARS-CoV-2 and the economic impact of COVID-19.

Bio:
Anton is an applied mathematician (PhD) with 28+ years of experience in algorithm development, scientific computing, mathematical modeling, natural language processing, combinatorial optimization, research and development programming, machine learning, and data mining.
In the last ten years, he focused on developing machine learning algorithms and workflows for different industries (music, movies, points of interests, recruiting, healthcare.) Currently, he is working on machine learning and data science applications to manufacturing (Industry 4.0.)
Anton is a former kernel developer of Mathematica.

title: Montreal R User Group: Explainable Data Science Workflows
description:
Register here: https://bit.ly/2wNL7eD

Learn explainable workflows using open source software, semi-automated pipelines, and Python! From data ingestion, cleaning, piping, and modeling, explainability and trust are at the forefront of enterprise data science initiatives. In this talk, learn the best practices for codifying and relaying explainable data science to stakeholders, management, and the end user in a reproducible and portable fashion.

In this talk you will learn:
- Best practices for explainable data science
- How to use Lale for semi-automated data science for portability and replicability
- How to utilize explainable algorithms and metrics for data science task

Must register to attend: https://bit.ly/2wNL7eD

Presented by Austin Eovito, Data Scientist, IBM

Austin is a Data Scientist on the Technical Marketing and Evangelism team in San Francisco, California. As a recent graduate student of Florida State University, Austin is focused on the balancing the bleeding-edge research produced by academia and the tools used in applied data science. His Masters thesis was on White Collar Crime using Time-aware Joint-Topic-Sentiment Analysis (TTS). Austin leads IBM's Data Science Masterclass on AI Explainability and currently resides in San Francisco, with his fiance, dog, and two cats.

title: Montreal R User Group: Virtual Training | Spark NLP for Data Scientists
description:
Register here: https://bit.ly/34jCvZu

Natural Language Processing (NLP) is a key component in many data science systems that must understand or reason about text. Common use cases include knowledge extraction, question answering, entity recognition, spell correction, sentiment analysis, and document classification.

This four-hour workshop will walk you through state-of-the-art natural language processing (NLP) using John Snow Labs’ open-source Spark NLP library. This is a hands-on workshop that will enable you to write, edit, and run live Python notebooks that cover the majority of the open-source library’s functionality.

The workshop is organized in three hour-long sessions, each followed by 30 minutes of self-guided coding, on Python notebooks relevant to each section. This is a live online workshop and the instructors will be available during the self-guided sessions to answer questions.

This workshop is part of the recommended preparation for the “Certified Spark NLP Data Scientist” certification exam.

title: Charlotte R Users Group: Charlotte R users Group: Brandon Beidel
description: Creating R projects that are easily shared across teams or even just across machines can be a challenge. Missing dependencies, incorrect package versions, and many other issues can plague you when attempting to share your work. Thankfully, tools like Docker and renv can be used in combination to ensure that every person who has access to your project can focus on the problem your code is trying to solve, not the environment. Brandon will share some lessons learned while addressing reproducibility problems in production machine learning systems at Red Ventures.

title: Salt Lake City R Users Group: [ONLINE] RStudio Tips for More Efficient R Coding
group: Salt Lake City R Users Group
description:
Our April Meetup will be our first ever remote gathering. Look for a Zoom link to be added soon!

In this presentation, Greg Snow, a statistical consultant for research at Intermountain Healthcare and an adjunct professor at BYU, will speak on lesser known tips for using the RStudio IDE.

RStudio is the most commonly used development environment for coding in R, and over the years RStudio has added many options to make life easier. This presentation will bring together and present many features that have not been widely advertised. Topics will include: rerun previous code block, outline mode and sectioning comments, code folding, jump to section, navigating between panes, pop-out panes, rename in scope, rectangle select/edit, extract variable, extract function, expand/shrink selection (brace, etc. matching), jump to function definition, find in files, and others (depending on time and interest).

title: Salt Lake City R Users Group: Regression When Your Data Isn't Well Behaved
group: Salt Lake City R Users Group
description:
Our May Meetup will be downtown at Intermountain Healthcare on the 16th floor of Key Bank Tower. You can access the lobby from doors along State Street or from the upper level of the City Creek mall just east of Johnny Rockets. City Creek has free two hour parking or you can take the Trax blue or green line to the City Center station.

The most commonly taught types of regression are linear (where the dependent variable can be any real number) and logistic (where the dependent variable is binary). However, many types of data don't fall into either of these two categories. In this session, we will review regression techniques that can handle other kinds of inputs: censored normal, logit-normal, and beta regression (for dependent variables that are bounded above and/or below); ordered logistic regression (for multiple discrete outcomes that are logically ordered, such as Likert ratings); and multinomial logistic regression (for discrete outcomes that aren't ordered). These techniques provide a better representation of the processes they are modeling and allow us to make more realistic predictions.

Abby Kaplan is a data scientist at Salt Lake Community College. Before joining SLCC, she was an adjunct professor of linguistics at the University of Utah. She received her PhD in linguistics from UC Santa Cruz in 2010.

title: Oslo useR! Group: R data.table := Tidy Data
description:
The data.table R package is fast and memory efficient. It uses a concise and consistent syntax for data processing. This workshop will take you through doing some data tidying by covering importing, wrangling, reshaping, merging and summarizing data. We will use the World Bank's Women in Parliament data to stimulate the programming and discussions.

The workshop will be a mix of presentations and hands on programming. The majority of the time will be spent doing exercises based on a real life example. Participants will be encouraged to work together and discuss.

Please bring a laptop with the latest version of R, RStudio and the data.table package installed.

Saghir Bashir is the founder of ilustat (https://ilustat.com), a data science training and consultancy company based in Portugal. He has a PhD in Biostatistics and is a long term SAS and R user (working with data.table, tidyverse, data visualization using ggplot2, statistical analysis, Shiny apps, customized R markdown, and much more). He has taught and teaches R to students and researchers at Lisbon University and in various meetup groups.

title: Oslo useR! Group: Workshop: Mild introduction to Structural Equation Modeling
description:
When working with data, we often want to create models to predict future events, but we also want an even deeper understanding of how our data is connected or structured. In this workshop, we will explore the connectedness of data using using structural equation modeling (SEM) with {lavaan} package.

NB! This event has been moved.

title: Turkish Community of R: R ile Veribilimi - WhyR 2020 ön buluşması | sabah sunumları
description:
English version follows below ;

WhyR Polonya ve melda.io ile işbirliği ile Yıldız Teknik Üniversitesinde 1 gün sürecek WhyR? 2020 Ön buluşması düzenliyoruz. Katılımın ücretsiz olacağı bu etkinliğin programında Polonya, Türkiye ve Bulgaristan’da veribilimi üzerine çalışan uzmanların yapacağı sabah sunumları ve pratik eğitim içeren akşamüstü seansı olacak.

Bu etkinlik sabah seansı içindir. Ücretsiz akşamüstü pratik eğitimine katılmak için o eğitime ayrıca kayıt olmanız gerekmektedir.

In close cooperation with WhyR Poland and melda.io, we are organizing a 1-day Why R? 2020 pre-meeting in Yıldız Teknik University. In this free event we have data science experts actively working in Poland, Turkey as well as a speaker Professor from YTÜ. The program will include a morning session with 3 presentations and an afternoon session for a selected audience hands-on training on Data Science with R.

This event is the morning talks given by invited speakers. If you want to attend the free afternoon training session you have to separately register for it.

Program
10.00 Opening
Gert Kroon PranaGEO CEO ve kurucu ortağı

10.15 Açılış Konuşması - R ile Web kazıma teknikleri
Olgun Aydin - PWC Polonya'da kıdemli veribilimci, Why-R Foundation üyesi

11.00 R ile tekrarlanabilir araştırma ve veribilim
Dr. Ahmet Çizmeli - PranaGEO CSO ve kurucu ortağı

11.45 Mekansal büyük veriler için veribilimi analizi
Dr. Alper ŞEN - Assist. Prof. Dr. Yildiz Teknik Üniversitesi

12.30 Öğle yemeği (katılımcılar yemek masraflarını kendileri karşılayacaklardır)

Güncelleme; Update;
Yaklaşmakta olan İstanbul ve Ankara etkinliklerimiz için Covid19 güncellemesi

En son COVID-19 (koronavirüs hastalığı) güncellemeleri nedeniyle, 24 Nisan'da İstanbul'da ve 27'de Ankara'da gerçekleştirmeyi planladığımız 2 etkinliğimizi aynı tarihlerde sanal etkinlikler olarak sunmayı planlıyoruz.
